May yt please yo
r
good L. the matter of
Berghen
wherof I
referred the report to this letter is thus in effect, The
Gouverno
r
is maried as yo
r
L. knoweth to
e eldest daughter
of
Merode
, a gentleman that liveth in a neutrall place, but is
partially affected to the Ennemies cause. I may well remember
that long since I adv
r
tized yo
r
L. of c
r
taine letters intercepted
by w
ch
it might appeare that the Bishop of
Liege
had
mised
Parma
to
swade w
th
Merode (whose abod ys commonlie in
e
Byshops Dyocesse) to practise w
th
his
daughter
& w
th
e
Gouverno
r
to surrender to towne into
e Enemies hands.
To bring this cunninglie to passe, both the father & the sonne
who is also for the Ennemie have bin busilie employed,
For they have sent at sondrie times both l
res
& messages
to
e Ladie Morgan (theyr hope to p
r
vaile being most of all
in her,) to dispose her affection to
e foresaid desseyn.
Espetiallie of late there was a messenger sent unto hir
who p
r
tended somewhat els to bee
e cause of his coming
but finding for his purpose a fitt opportunitie, p
r
sented unto
her a letter from her father; w
ch
being but of credence, before
he would declare the effect of his message hee fell dowen
upon his knees, and besought her w
th
teares, to pardon whatsoever
hee should utter unto her, w
ch
when shee had promised, after
hee had used those complements. w
ch
hee was willed from
her father, w
ch
were full of kinde
testations of his fatherlie
affection, hee told her in
e end, That
e onelie thing wherin
her father desired to bee grateified by her, wherby shee might
also make her self great, & do a singular
s
rvice to God &
e
countrey, was to Induce her husband to resigne his gov
r
ment
to
e hand
of
e
King
. Hee should bee rewarded for yt, w
th
such hono
rs
and Dignities, as no man before had Receaved
the like for
e like kinde of service. This was presently
discovered by
e Lady Morgan to her husband, nev
r
theles shee
entreated him in regard of her woord, to bee silent in the
matter toward
e messenger, w
ch
though hee
mised in
respect of
e messenger, and suffered him as then to de
te
awaie quietlie, yet hee made
e matter knowen to
e
Councell
of State
. Moreover this being don about two moneths past
the self same messenger is newly come againe, coullouring
his coming wth matters of contribution; but bringing secretly
w
th
him an other letter from her father. Wherby the
Gouverno
r
ceaving that hee was sharplie bent to poursue this

enterprise, caused an officer to speake upon him & sent him hither
to
e Councell. and hee examined hee confesseth as much as
I have signified before. The Councell of state albeit
in
theye
do acknowledge, that they have bin allwaies in theyr warres
most faithfullie
s
rved by
e Gouverno
r
, & will not seeme in
this action to have him in suspition, yet consydering his estate
w
ch
they think doth much depend upon
e benefit of that
Gouvernment, they feare very much in
cesse of time, the father
wilbee able to
swade w
th
his daughter, & that shee may
finde the meanes to
swade her husband, or at the least to
make some ouverture, wh
r
by the Towne in continuance may
be wonne by surprise. For p
r
vention wh
r
of, they have had
the matter in debate, & have thought yt very requesyt yf
there could bee any meanes to
vide the Gouverno
r
of some
other gouverment (where they might not stand in feare of the foresayd
practises) that hee should bee then removed w
th
e first opportunity.
Alwaies und
r
stood that no alteration should bee made w
th
out her
Ma
tyes
allowance &
e Gouvernors contentation. Not to trouble yo
r
L. w
th
ev
r
y circumstance, It was supposed heer in Councell, that
my
L. Burgh
by reason of his youth & vallo
r
might affect some
place of continuall
s
rvice against
e ennemy, & in that behalf bee
desirous to exchange his garrison for that of Berghen. Wh
r
uppon
they concluded yf
ey found him willing th
r
unto, to entreat her
Hig
nes
by theyr letters to conferr the
Brill
upon
e Gouverno
r
of
Berghen. For there they are assured there is no daunger of
surprise, & those counterfait occasions of the ennemies often sending
will surcease of them selves. To know
e sooner in that matter
wh
r
unto they might trust, they were earnest w
th
mee to use some
conference w
th
my L. & to feele his disposition for accepting that offer.
Howbeyt my L. for divers causes, but spetially disliking to hold
any gouverment from
e
States
would not hearken to
e motion.
w
ch
being c
r
tified unto them, because they knowe no oth
r
waie, that
wilbe pleasing to
e Gouverno
r
, they have thought it expedient to
proceed no farder in
e matter. Nev
r
theles they have determined
to execute
e
tie, that und
r
tooke the foresaid message, hoping th
r
by
that either Merode & the Ennemy will despaire of theyr purpose
& so give over those attempt
, or that at least by that meanes
they shall finde no more instrument
to deliver such errandes.
This consultation of the Councell hath bin warely held, w
th
out
the privity of
e Gouverno
r
, or of any man els, that is not of
the Councel, my L. Burgh excepted.
Lest
happely
this mater
should come in q
u
stion againe, or by those that knowe to not directly
be misrepeated to her Hig
nes
. I thought it my duty to declare it wholy
as it was and so I take my humble leave
